headline: Lowe's still seeking more from Woolworths over Masters
text:
US home improvement retailer Lowe's has written down its stake in the Masters joint venture with Woolworths to just $US103 million ($136 million) but is still seeking a much higher price for its one-third share.

Lowe's and Woolworths have been in court-ordered arbitration since late last year over the amount Woolworths must pay Lowe's for its share of the now defunct Masters chain and Home Timber & Hardware, which has been sold to Metcash.

Woolworths is believed to have offered to pay Lowe's about $180 million from net proceeds of $500 million, but Lowe's believed its stake was worth closer to $600 million.

In its annual report, released in the US on Tuesday, Lowe's said it recorded a $US290 million non-cash impairment charge in the third quarter of fiscal 2016 to reflect its estimated portion of the overall fair value of the joint venture as it was wound down. This followed a $US530 million non-cash impairment charge in fiscal 2015.
